data.title: Find out what extension is causing what behavior
data.body:
- VSCode Version: all
- OS Version: any

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install several related extensions and find some unexpected behavior afterwards.
2. Become dumbfounded because you can't tell which extension is causing which behavior, particularly the unexpected behavior.
3. Uninstall them one by one until the unexpected behavior stops.

I don't know what the general solution to this is, but I hope you brilliant people at Microsoft start looking at implementing one soon. For example, tonight, I installed a number of extensions for javascript. Now whenever I save a js file, the file is auto-formatted with the wrong spacing. I have already disabled format on save everywhere it exists in the configuration, yet it still formats incorrectly upon save. How can I fix this problem short of step 3, and prevent the problem entirely, short of step 1? How can I find out what extension is causing bad behavior?

data.title: VS Code Needs an Extension Blacklist
data.body:
- VSCode Version: all
- OS Version: any

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install several interesting-looking extensions
2. Find some of them suck and you never want to install them again, but no ability to mark them as ignored, or bad or blacklisted.
3. Months later install several similar interesting-looking extensions
4. Find some of the same ones still suck and you still never want to install them again, but VS Code lacks the feature to ignore or blacklist extensions you definitely don't want.

data.title: Provide a command to close all unchanged files
data.body:
New Feature (#25667) - Support to bulk close Unmodified Files
### Change Summary
- Editor Action Support for Closing Unmodified files in a group from
  1. Explorer Open Editor's context menu 
![closeviaexplorercontextmenu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1210516/25563840/0ba56d74-2de8-11e7-85cf-9ae9cfd6866b.gif)


  2. Editor Tab context menu 
![closeviaeditortabcontextmenu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1210516/25563835/003e7fc0-2de8-11e7-9414-144eb252a7e4.gif)


  3. Command Palette
![closeviacommandpalette](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1210516/25563790/d610ebbc-2de6-11e7-8401-5560534e0fc5.gif)


- Test updates
- Interface methods implemented in the affected source and tests 

### Scenarios Handled
   - Action will close only the unmodified files in a targetted group
   - Only the active group with an active editor will be targetted when executed from the Command palette
   - In explorer the group targetted will be of the file on which the context menu is triggered.
   - If the menu is accessed via the context menu from the Editor tab that group will be the target
   - If there are no editors open and the command is invoked from the command palette it is ignored
   - Group is closed if all editors are unmodified
   - Action can be triggered using the keyboard shortcut

Please let me know if some scenario is missed.

data.title: Focus follows mouse
data.body:
Feature request.

I, like many on Linux, have my system configured in "focus follows mouse," meaning that I can hover the mouse over a window and start typing. This makes it easier to work with many terminals, editors, and browser windows at the same time, because you don't need to click inside a window (and thus raise it, and move the cursor position...) for it to get keyboard focus. This is usually paired with a theme that gives a strong visual cue to the current window. (In my case, the focused window has a bright orange border, while all others have a dim blue one.)

I would love to have a similar setting for VSCode, so that the keyboard focus would follow the editor pane (or terminal, or sidebar, or find bar...) where the mouse is currently hovering.

For the visual cue, see #25191

data.title: Inline snippets should have lower precedence then actual properties if no match.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.12.0-insider (0bec115779b11a9d78bdb24ad7918c22524ea2ac, 2017-04-28T18:57:52.518Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.0|
|gitignore|codezombiech|0.5.0|
|bracket-pair-colorizer|CoenraadS|0.10.3|
|tslint|eg2|0.12.0|
|vscode-postfix-ts|ipatalas|1.3.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  `"editor.snippetSuggestions": "inline"`
2. Have lots of snippets, i.e. use `postfix` extension
3. Bring up intellisense on an object

When there is nothing matched yet, snippets should have a default lower ranking then actual properties. Often I use intellisense to discover properties on an object, now I have to scroll down past all my snippets. I don't want to set `"editor.snippetSuggestions": "bottom"` because I still want them to match when I do start typing.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5593825/25557082/ffc8df9c-2d09-11e7-8ae8-9ae85e8737bd.png)

data.title: Tooltips on imports are useless
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.0-insider (0bec1157)
- OS Version: Windows 10

If you have an ES6 import like so:

```
import { someFunction } from './myfile.js';
```

I get the JSDoc for `someFunction` when I use it, but if I simply hover over the import, the tooltip reads `import someFunction`.  There is opportunity to show the JSDoc which would be far more relevant. For reference, I'm using TypeScript.

![useless](http://i.imgur.com/obIVeJ0.png)

![not useless](http://i.imgur.com/N0Y8oLw.png)

data.title: CDATA sections in XML files not collapsed properly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open an XML file containing CDATA, for example:

    ```xml
    <RootTag>
        <AnotherTag>
            <YetAnotherTag>
                <![CDATA[
    some CDATA contents
     ]]>
            </YetAnotherTag>
        </AnotherTag>
    </RootTag>
    ```
2. Try to collapse a tag that contains CDATA, like `<AnotherTag>`.
3. Notice that the CDATA section is not collapsed, even though it is part of the tag that I tried to collapse:

   ![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/287848/25556692/49cd11e8-2d01-11e7-875c-eecb9d09f3c8.png)

data.title: Incorrect size of Markdown preview when non-zero zoom level
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e, 2017-04-13T08:03:11.395Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `"window.zoomLevel": 2` // Anything other than 0
2. Open a markdown file and start preview. The preview window will be small than the space available for it.

The issue also happens with side-by-side preview.

data.title: host_name() in SQL Server Vnext in Visual Studio Code returns NULL
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: Windows 10

I am using SQL Server Vnext CTP 2.0 on Windows 10. 

SELECT host_name() 

function returns null if I use "Visual Studio Code" as client whereas it returns correct server name if I use SQL Server Management Studio 11 for SQL Server 2017.

FYI..

SELECT @@SERVERNAME

Returns correct instance name in Visual Studio Code.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install SQL Server Vnext CTP 2.0
2. Install Visual Studio Code
3. Connect SQL Server using Visual Studio Code on SQL login
4. Run above "SELECT host_name()" query

data.title: Source control doesn't detect changes when changing from symlink to normal file
data.body: When changing a symlink to a normal file with the same name in a Git repository, VSCode doesn't show any changes in Source Control. - VSCode Version: Version 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e) - OS Version: macOS 10.12.4 (16E195) - Git version: 2.12.0 Steps to Reproduce: ``` ~ $ mkdir tsrepro ~ $ cd tsrepro/ ~/tsrepro $ touch README ~/tsrepro $ ln -s README README-2 ~/tsrepro $ git init Initialized empty Git repository in /xxx/tsrepro/.git/ ~/tsrepro $ git add . ~/tsrepro $ git commit -m "Initial commit" [master (root-commit) 9901b0b] Initial commit 2 files changed, 1 insertion(+) create mode 100644 README create mode 120000 README-2 ~/tsrepro $ code . ~/tsrepro $ rm README-2 ~/tsrepro $ echo "Now a file" > README-2 ~/tsrepro $ git status On branch master Changes not staged for commit: (use "git add ..." to update what will be committed) (use "git checkout -- ..." to discard changes in working directory) typechange: README-2 no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a") ``` Source control is empty:

data.title: Formatting: space is not added in parenthesis with arrow function
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.12.0-insider (0bec115779b11a9d78bdb24ad7918c22524ea2ac, 2017-04-28T18:57:52.518Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set a following option in your user/workspace settings:
`	"javascript.format.insertSpaceAfterOpeningAndBeforeClosingNonemptyParenthesis": true`
1. Open a new file, set language to JavaScript.
1. Paste a following snippet:
```javascript
foo( () => 1 );
foo( 1 );
```
1. Press `ctrl/cmd+shift+f`.

### Expected

The code stays the way it is.

### Actual

Initial space gets removed.

```javascript
foo(() => 1 );
foo( 1 );
```

## Additional Info

Checked also on a regular VSCode installation.

data.title: Provide a command to close all unchanged files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: all
- OS Version: all

At work I use this editor heavily and sometimes end up in a situation where lots of editor are open.
It will be great if there is an option to close all unchanged files quickly.
Happy to raise a pull request for this as well !

- Editor Action Support for Closing Unmodified files in a group from
  1. Explorer Open Editor's context menu 
![closeviaexplorercontextmenu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1210516/25563840/0ba56d74-2de8-11e7-85cf-9ae9cfd6866b.gif)


  2. Editor Tab context menu 
![closeviaeditortabcontextmenu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1210516/25563835/003e7fc0-2de8-11e7-9414-144eb252a7e4.gif)


  3. Command Palette
![closeviacommandpalette](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1210516/25563790/d610ebbc-2de6-11e7-8401-5560534e0fc5.gif)
